description: From Middle English repreven, reproven, from Anglo-Norman reprover, Middle French reprouver, from Latin reprobāre. Doublet of reprobate.

verbs.description: reprove (third-person singular simple present reproves, present participle reproving, simple past and past participle reproved)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to criticise, rebuke or reprimand (someone), usually in a gentle and kind tone. [from 14th c.]
(transitive) to deny or reject (a feeling, behaviour, action etc.). [from 14th c.]
examples: She ached to be with Affad again – and to reprove the feeling she frowned and bit her lip.

verbs.description: reprove (third-person singular simple present reproves, present participle reproving, simple past reproved, past participle reproved or (rare) reproven)
